item.gloss: Witness: godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
Nonage: ‘The state of being under full legal age; minority', OEDO.
Prove: 'to test', OEDO.
Amain: ‘immediately’, OEDO.
Surfeit: 'Excessive consumption of food or drink', OEDO.
Measles: 'various diseases causing a red rash', OEDO. See Alan Dyer, ‘Epidemics of Measles in a Seventeenth Century English Town’, Local Population Studies 34 (1985): 35–45.
Sweet: ‘Having pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Quality: ‘rank in society’, OEDO.
Painful care: 'Of an action, occupation, etc.: performed with or involving great care or diligence', OEDO.
The stone: 'A kidney or bladder stone’, OEDO.
Shipman: 'Archaic word for sailor or seaman', OEDO.
Surfeit: 'Excessive consumption of food or drink', OEDO.
Pleurisy: 'an abscess of the ribs or inner surface of the chest’, OEDO. See Adrian Wilson, ‘On the History of Disease-Concepts: The Case of Pleurisy’, History of Science 38, no. 3 (2000): 271–319.
Wath: 'A ford; a fordable stream', OEDO.
Ague: 'An acute or high fever; disease, or a disease, characterized by such fever, esp. when recurring periodically’, OEDO.
Jaundice: 'A morbid condition caused by obstruction of the bile, and characterized by yellowness’, OEDO.

Witness: godparent, usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
Ague: 'an acute or high fever; disease, or a disease, characterized by such fever, esp. when recurring periodically’, OEDO.
Jaundice: 'A morbid condition caused by obstruction of the bile, and characterized by yellowness’, OEDO.
Travail: 'The effort and pain of childbirth; labour’, OEDO.
Consumption: 'Abnormality or loss of humours, resulting in wasting', OEDO.
Stitch: 'A sharp sudden local pain’, OEDO.
Phlegm: 'One of the four cardinal humours, described as cold and moist', OEDO.

Sanctification: ’The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections. Also, the condition or process of being so sanctified', OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Chiefest: 'At the head or top in importance; most important, influential', OEDO.
Quire: 'That part of a church appropriated to the singers; spec. the part eastward of the nave', OEDO.
Surety: 'A godparent', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way’, OEDO.
Droil: 'Drudgery; toil in disagreeable work', OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Gentle, easy,’ OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Gentle, easy,’ OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Quick with child: 'Pregnant with a live fetus; spec. at a stage of pregnancy when movements of the fetus have been felt', OEDO. This means Thornton was about five months pregnant.
Plaster: 'A solid medicinal or emollient substance spread on a bandage or dressing and applied to the skin, often becoming adhesive at body temperature', OEDO.
Steer: 'A young ox, esp. one which has been castrated', OEDO.
Steer: 'A young ox, esp. one which has been castrated', OEDO.
Draught: 'A team of horses or other beasts of draught, together with that which they draw', OEDO. Here the latter.
Steer: 'A young ox, esp. one which has been castrated', OEDO.
Martinmas: '(The date of) the feast of St Martin, 11 November', OEDO.
Executor: 'A person appointed by a testator to execute or carry into effect his or her will after his or her decease', OEDO.
Michaelmas: 'The feast of St Michael (St Michael and all Angels), one of the quarter days in England, Ireland, and Wales; the date of this, 29 September', OEDO.
Worm: 'A human being likened to a worm or reptile as an object of contempt, scorn, or pity; an abject, miserable creature', OEDO.
Execution: 'The seizure of the goods or person of a debtor in default of payment', OEDO.
Assignment: 'Appointment to office, nomination, designation', OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Execution: 'The seizure of the goods or person of a debtor in default of payment', OEDO.
Bailiff: 'An officer of justice under a sheriff, who executes writs and processes, distrains, and arrests; a warrant officer, pursuivant, or catchpoll', OEDO.
Plate: 'Gold or silver vessels and utensils', OEDO.
Quick goods: 'Quick or live animals, livestock', Yorkshire Historical Dictionary, online, https://yorkshiredictionary.york.ac.uk/words/quick%20goods
Apprehensions: ‘the action of “feeling” anything emotionally; sensitiveness’, OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On Protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), ch. 2.
Quickened: ‘Made living or lively; animated, revived, stimulated,’ OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three ‘persons’ or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘secular as opposed to sacred,’ OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Travail: 'The effort and pain of childbirth; labour’, OEDO.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.

Flux: ‘An abnormally copious flowing of blood’, OEDO. Used here to refer to postpartum uterine bleeding. See Leah Astbury, ‘Being Well, Looking Ill': Childbirth and the Return to Health in Seventeenth-Century England’, Social History of Medicine 30, no. 3 (2017): 506.
Candlemas: 'The feast of the purification of the Virgin Mary (or presentation of Christ in the Temple) celebrated with a great display of candles', OEDO. This is celebrated on 2 February.
Worm: 'A human being likened to a worm or reptile as an object of contempt, scorn, or pity', OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three ‘persons’ or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Competency: ‘A sufficient supply; a sufficiency of,’ OEDO.
Travail: 'The effort and pain of childbirth; labour’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.
Wretch: ‘one of opprobrious or reprehensible character; a mean or contemptible creature,’ OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Distemper: 'Derangement or disturbance of the “humour” or “temper”', OEDO.
Palsy: 'Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor’, OEDO.
Convulsion: 'An involuntary contraction, stiffening, or “drawing up” of a muscle, limb, etc.', OEDO.
High: ‘Great, or greater than normal, in amount, level, size, or intensity; extreme; strong, forcible, violent’, OEDO.
Discomforted: ‘To deprive of courage or strength of mind; to discourage, dishearten, dismay', OEDO.
Peradventure: ‘Expressing a hypothetical, contingent or uncertain possibility: perhaps, maybe, possibly', OEDO.
Vouchsafed: ‘To show a gracious readiness or willingness, to grant readily, to condescend or deign, to do something,’ OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious’, OEDO.
Actual sin: 'Sin committed through a person's own actions; opposed to original sin', OEDO.
Repine: 'To feel or express discontent or dissatisfaction; to grumble, complain', OEDO.
Worm: 'A human being likened to a worm or reptile as an object of contempt, scorn, or pity; an abject, miserable creature', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘secular as opposed to sacred,’ OEDO.
Sanctification: ’The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections', OEDO.
Red spot: ‘Any small red lesion of the skin (as a macule, papule, etc.), esp. one forming part of a rash', OEDO.
Mourn: 'To make a low inarticulate sound indicative of grief, pain, hunger, etc.; to moan', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way’, OEDO.
Ravished: ‘to transport (a person, the mind, etc.) with the strength of some emotion; to fill with ecstasy, intense delight, or sensuous pleasure; to entrance, captivate, or enrapture’, OEDO.
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.
Fruit: ' An embryo, fœtus’, OEDO.
Quick with child: 'Pregnant with a live fetus; spec. at a stage of pregnancy when movements of the fetus have been felt', OEDO. This means Thornton was about five months pregnant.
Flood: 'A popular term for uterine hæmorrhage, esp. in connection with parturition', OEDO.
Bole armeniac: 'An astringent earth brought from Armenia, and formerly used as an antidote and styptic', OEDO.
Claret: 'A name originally given (like French vin clairet) to wines of yellowish or light red colour, as distinguished alike from “red wine” and “white wine”', OEDO.
Loaf sugar: 'Sugar refined and moulded into a loaf or conical mass', OEDO.
Consumption: 'Abnormality or loss of humours, resulting in wasting', OEDO.
Skrike: 'A shrill cry, a screech', OEDO.
Distemper: 'Derangement or disturbance of the “humour” or “temper”', OEDO.
Cordial: ‘A food or (esp. alcoholic) drink with medicinal or health-giving properties, esp. one that is thought to invigorate the heart, stimulate the circulation, or provide comfort,’ OEDO.
Scurf: 'A morbid condition of the skin, esp. of the head, characterized by the separation of branny scales, without inflammation', OEDO.
Keeper: ‘A nurse; one who has charge of the sick,’ OEDO.
Ague: 'An acute or high fever; disease, or a disease, characterized by such fever, esp. when recurring periodically’, OEDO.
The stone: ' Bladder or kidney stones', OEDO.
Understanding: 'Power or ability to understand; intellect, intelligence', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way; favourably’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Favour: 'Appearance, aspect, look', OEDO.

Phlegm: 'In ancient and medieval physiology and medicine: one of the four cardinal humours, described as cold and moist, and supposed when predominant to cause constitutional indolence or apathy', OEDO.
Intermitting: 'Marked by an intermission (of fever)', OEDO.
Strait: 'Of a way, passage, or channel: So narrow as to make transit difficult', OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc.); an instance of this; a violent outburst', OEDO.
Pearl: 'Any white lesion of the eye, esp. a corneal opacity or a cataract', OEDO.
Comrade: ‘Generally, a close companion, mate, fellow,’ OEDO.
Quick with child: 'Pregnant with a live fetus; spec. at a stage of pregnancy when movements of the fetus have been felt', OEDO. This means Thornton was about five months pregnant.
Palsy: 'Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor; an instance of this’, OEDO.
Michaelmas: 'The feast of St Michael (St Michael and all Angels), one of the quarter days in England, Ireland, and Wales; the date of this, 29 September', OEDO.
Intermitted: 'To cease or stop for a time', OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On Protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), ch. 2.
Fits: ’A sudden, transient episode of fever, often with chills’, OEDO.
Travail: 'The effort and pain of childbirth; labour', OEDO.
Reins of the back: 'The region of the kidneys', OEDO.
Mother: 'The uterus', OEDO.
Childbed: ’The state of a woman in labour, childbirth‘, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear,’ OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear’, OEDO.
Lovely: ‘ Lovable; deserving of love or admiration’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear,’ OEDO.
Red gum: 'A bright red, maculopapular rash seen in infants and young children, often during teething', OEDO.
Looseness: 'Laxity (of the bowels), esp. as a morbid symptom; diarrhoea', OEDO.
Gangrene: 'A small circumscribed ulcer on the skin, esp. on the leg or in the mouth (obsolete)', OEDO.
Intermission: ' Temporary cessation, respite, relief, rest, pause’,, OEDO.
Fits: 'Originally: a sudden, transient episode of fever’, OEDO.
Spleen: 'A grudge; a spite or ill-will', OEDO.
Unhandsomely: ‘Discourteously, rudely; without due respect or consideration,’ OEDO.
Redeemed: 'Of a person, a soul, etc.: saved or delivered from sin, damnation, or criminality', OEDO.
Blazed: ‘To decry, defame, hold up to infamy,’ OEDO.
Plausible: ‘Of a person, a person's manners, etc.: affable, pleasant, winning, ingratiating,’ OEDO.
Regeneration: 'The period of Christ's teaching ministry on earth', OEDO.
Lathe: 'A barn', OEDO.
Mow: 'A place in a barn where hay or corn is heaped up', OEDO.
Pathetical: ‘Expressing or arising from passion or strong emotion; passionate, emotional; earnest,’ OEDO.
Larum: 'A warning of the imminent danger of attack by a hostile force', OEDO
Calumnies: ‘a false charge or imputation, intended to damage another's reputation; a slanderous report,’ OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc)', OEDO.
Mother: 'The uterus', OEDO.
Subtlety: ‘A cunning or crafty scheme; a trick; a clever stratagem’, OEDO.
Dissembling: ‘To put on a feigned or false appearance of; to feign, pretend, simulate', OEDO.
Smitten: ‘To strike or hit (a person or thing), usually forcefully', OEDO.
Condole: ‘To grieve with; to express sympathy with another in his affliction,’ OEDO.
Candour: ‘Freedom from malice, favourable disposition, kindliness,’ OEDO.
Recruited: ‘To regain (one's spirits, health, strength, etc.); to refresh or reinvigorate', OEDO.
Adventure: ‘Any undertaking the outcome of which is uncertain; an experiment; a test of luck’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc.)', OEDO.
Consummate: ‘To make perfect; to perfect’ – in the sense of ‘to bring to completion; to finish, carry out, accomplish’, OEDO.
Sanctification: 'The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections’, OEDO.
Incomprehensible: ‘That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless, infinite; immense,’ OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred,’ OEDO.
Filial: 'Of sentiments, duty, etc.: Due from a child to a parent', OEDO.

Old Adam: i.e., Adam [and Eve], as opposed to Christ the ‘second Adam’. On the first and second Adam in early modern theology see Willem J. van Asselt, ‘Christ, Predestination, and Covenant in Post-Reformation Reformed Theology’, The Oxford Handbook of Early Modern Theology 1600-1800 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2016), 223.
Distemper: 'Derangement or disturbance of the “humour” or “temper”', OEDO.
Latest: 'Last, final', OEDO.
Art: ‘An acquired ability of any kind; a skill at doing a specified thing, typically acquired through study and practice,’ OEDO.
Frame: ‘The physical body, esp. that of a human being, usually with reference to its build or constitution; physique,’ OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Forenoon: 'The portion of the day before noon', OEDO.
Sweetly: ‘In a desirable or satisfactory way; favourably; delicately … smoothly, easily’ OEDO.
Alley: 'A passage between the rows of pews or seats in a church’, OEDO.
Damask: ‘The colour of the damask rose', OEDO.
Poetaster: 'An inferior poet; a writer of poor or trashy verse; a mere versifier', OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Philistine: 'A member of a non-Semitic people occupying the southern coast of Palestine in biblical times, who came into conflict with the Israelites during the 12th and 11th centuries b.c.', OEDO.
Catholic: ‘Designating the whole Christian Church or all Christians collectively’, OEDO.
Sustentation: ‘Patience, forbearance', OEDO.
Sanctification: ’The action of the Holy Spirit in sanctifying or making holy the believer, by the implanting within him of the Christian graces and the destruction of sinful affections', OEDO.
Incomprehensible: ' That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless, infinite; immense’, OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.
Raw-boned: 'Having projecting bones barely covered with flesh; extremely lean or gaunt', OEDO.

Providence: 'In full providence of God (also nature, etc.), divine providence. The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Childbed: 'The bed in which a child is born', OEDO. 2.
Couch: ' A frame or structure, with what is spread over it (or simply a layer of some soft substance), on which to lie down for rest or sleep; a bed’, OEDO.
Child wife: 'A woman in labour, or who has recently given birth', OEDO.

Venturous: ‘Disposed to venture upon or undertake something of a dangerous or risky nature; willing to take risks or incur danger; bold, daring, or enterprising in action or opinion; adventurous, venturesome', OEDO.
Resolution: 'Determination; firmness or steadfastness of purpose', OEDO.
Divine: ‘A theologian', OEDO.

Sequestration: 'The appropriation of the income of a property in order to satisfy claims against the owner', OEDO. Sequestration by the state was very common during, and after, the Wars of the Three Kingdoms.
Distraining: ‘To constrain or force (a person) by the seizure and detention of a chattel or thing; to punish by such seizure and detention for the non-performance of such obligation', OEDO.

Mitigation: 'Abatement or relaxation of the severity or rigour of a law, penalty, etc.; extenuation or palliation of an offence, fault, etc.; abatement or minimization of the loss or damage resulting from a wrongful act', OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hurt, harm, mischief or injury done or caused by another,’ OEDO.

Providence: 'In full providence of God (also nature, etc.), divine providence. The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Portion: 'The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate', OEDO.

Ravish: ‘To drag off or carry away (a woman) by force or with violence (occasionally also implying subsequent rape).’ OEDO. Here, on the line above, Thornton does associate the act with the threat of rape.
